Sentencas: A model for the description of transport and electrochemical processes in solid oxide fuel cell (SPEC) electrodes is presented in this study.

Sentencas: Effective transport and reaction properties are evaluated using a Monte Carlo random walk method on electrodes numerically reconstructed with a packing algorithm.

Sentencas: This approach overcomes limitations of typical micro-modeling studies on SOFCs, wherein effective microstructural properties are estimated using empirical correlations or fitted on experimental data.

Sentencas: Throughout the entire modeling framework in this study, no fitted or empirical parameters are used.

Sentencas: Effective properties as a function of porosity and particle size are calculated and reported in dimensionless form to provide generality in their application.

Sentencas: A good agreement with independent experimental data for both gas and solid phases is achieved.

Sentencas: The model predictions can be used to improve the design of composite electrodes for solid oxide fuel cells.

Sentencas: In particular, simulation results show that porosity lower than 0.20 and particle size smaller than 0.2 mu m should be avoided in the design of SOFC composite cathodes because, under these conditions, Knudsen effects limit the mass transport with a significant reduction in the electrode performance.
